item.title: 33 TV Shows to Watch This Winter: ‘Wonder Man,’ ‘Outlander’ and More
item.description: “Malcolm in the Middle”? “Scrubs”? Patrick Dempsey? In 2026, everything old is comfortable again.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.category: The Last Thing He Told Me (TV Program)
item.media:description: Zach Braff, top, and Donald Faison return for a revival of “Scrubs,” premiering Feb. 25 on ABC.

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2 Premiere Recap: The Doctors Will See You Now
item.description: Doctor Robby is back for one final shift before he goes on sabbatical. What could possibly go wrong?
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Season 2 of “The Pitt” opened by showing viewers a side of Dr. Robby (Noah Wyle) they hadn’t seen before.

item.title: Think Punk Rockers Are Angry? Meet These Menopausal Women.
item.description: The BritBox show “Riot Women” follows an all-female band navigating the challenges of middle age — a subject that its creator, Sally Wainwright, knows well.
item.dc:creator: Eleanor Stanford
item.media:description: From left: Amelia Bullmore, Rosalie Craig and Tamsin Greig in “Riot Women.”

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Asks: Is TV Better in Small Doses?
item.description: The hospital drama has become the champion of a return to old-fashioned weekly viewing habits. But honestly, it makes a pretty great binge watch.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: Colossal Athletes Fill These Modern Arenas
item.description: Cosm, a company once focused on planetarium displays, is immersing sports fans with giant screens and desirable angles.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan and Jamie Lee Taete
item.media:description: Fans watching an N.B.A. game at Cosm in Inglewood, Calif., could hear the squeaking of sneakers and see the rim shaking after a dunk.

item.title: On ‘Best Medicine,’ Josh Charles Has a Heart
item.description: After years of playing smarmy characters, the actor is stepping up as the lead in a comedy about a grumpy but charming doctor.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Peter Fisher for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s been feast or famine,” the actor Josh Charles said of his career in movies, TV and theater. He added: “I just want to do good work.”

item.title: He’s Chevy Chase, and He’s Still Like That
item.description: The famously prickly comedian found a sympathetic adversary in the director of a CNN documentary about him. Their conversation with a reporter was … spirited.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.category: I'm Chevy Chase and You're Not (Movie)
item.media:credit: Blaise Cepis for The New York Times
item.media:description: “He had looks and talent, and he had a chance,” Zenovich said of Chase, adding, “He made it as much as he could, but I think he turned to drugs and drinking to stop the pain.”

item.title: ‘Stranger Things’ Has Ended. What Happened in the Series Finale?
item.description: There was a lot to tie up after five seasons and nearly 10 years, and the show gave itself another two hours to do it. Here are the major events.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.media:description: Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown, right, with Linnea Berthelsen) had a very difficult choice to make in the “Stranger Things” series finale.

item.title: Marcello Hernández Can Handle the Haters
item.description: He once thought his comedy career was over before it even began. Now he’s an “S.N.L.” star with a Netflix special coming in January.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff and OK McCausland
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times

item.title: How Kit Harington Left Jon Snow Behind
item.description: The actor crashed after “Game of Thrones.” Now, as he returns in a new season of “Industry” on HBO, he feels like “one of the luckiest people alive.”
item.dc:creator: Miles Ellingham and Charlotte Hadden
item.media:credit: Charlotte Hadden for The New York Times

item.title: Timothy Busfield, Actor and Director, Is Accused of Child Sex Abuse
item.description: The Emmy Award-winning actor is accused of abusing two child actors while working on a television series. An arrest warrant was issued in New Mexico.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Timothy Busfield in Pasadena, Calif. in 2020.

item.title: Golden Globes 2026: What to Expect From Sunday’s Awards Ceremony
item.description: Keep an eye on “One Battle After Another,” which is likely to dominate, and on the speeches. A particularly memorable one could be an Oscar lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene at a preview event for the Golden Globes, being held Sunday at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Bob the Drag Queen Is ‘Fully Obsessed’ With League of Legends
item.description: “I see why nerd culture is so exciting and fun,” said the “Drag Race” alum ahead of his Broadway debut in “Moulin Rouge.”
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck
item.media:credit: Amy Sussman/Getty Images for Mistr, Free Onl

item.title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a film sequel to a beloved franchise and a documentary about the plight of polar bears.
item.dc:creator: Dina Gachman
item.category: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: The Last Straw (Movie)

item.title: Late Night Is Distracted by Kristi Noem’s Oversized Cowboy Hat
item.description: “Why is Kristi Noem always in some sort of cosplay outfit?” Seth Meyers asked on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Bug’ Review: Carrie Coon Is Superb in an American Gothic Tale
item.description: Tracy Letts’s eerily topical, decades-old play about a woman’s descent into a world of conspiracy theories makes its nerve-rattling Broadway debut.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:description: Carrie Coon and Namir Smallwood in Tracy Letts’s stylistically slippery “Bug” at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Stars of ‘The Pitt’ Gathered At HBO’s Premiere Party to Toast Season 2
item.description: At the premiere of Season 2 in Los Angeles, the cast and crew of HBO Max’s hyper-realistic medical drama learned the show would be renewed.
item.dc:creator: Juno Carmel and Alex Welsh
item.category: Sunset Tower Hotel (Los Angeles, Calif, Hotel)
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

item.title: Can Shawn Levy Resuscitate ‘Star Wars’?
item.description: Lucasfilm hopes that Shawn Levy, who made “Deadpool and Wolverine” and helped make “Stranger Things,” can bring that same touch. The key may be his inner child.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.media:credit: Max Miechowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m the guy the studios call when they want someone they know will take their investment seriously and deliver responsibly,” Shawn Levy said.

item.title: Josh O’Connor’s Masterly 2025 Performances: ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’ and More
item.description: The star’s nuance and emotional power, along with his natural charisma, quietly enriched a quartet of movies in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: Late Night Responds to Trump’s Bid to Be an Oil Baron
item.description: Jimmy Kimmel said it was good President Trump would be in charge of Venezuela’s oil sales: “That way we know it will be spent honestly.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Ronny Chieng Remarks on Trump ‘DoorDash-ing’ Maduro to Brooklyn
item.description: “The Daily Show” host quipped that after a surprise capture, Nicolás Maduro “will face justice in the best legal system in the world that we illegally kidnapped him to.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix

Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: From ‘Star Trek’ to ‘Stranger Things,’ What Hive Minds Tell Us About Ourselves
item.description: Many people, one brain. It’s a classic storytelling device, and it’s showing up a lot more lately.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips
item.media:description: The children of “Village of the Damned” are one of many examples of the hive mind at work in pop culture over the years.

item.title: Stephen Colbert Doubts Trump Can Run Two Countries at Once
item.description: “The Late Show” host said the president couldn’t possibly run two nations, because “he can’t even run.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Disney+, Amazon, HBO Max, Peacock and More in January
item.description: “The Pitt” Season 2, “Star Trek: Starfleet Academy,” “The Beauty,” “Wonder Man,” “Shrinking” Season 3 and more arrive.

item.title: The Most Anticipated Book Adaptations of 2026: Movies and TV Shows
item.description: “People We Meet on Vacation,” “Wuthering Heights” and “Project Hail Mary” are some of this year’s most anticipated adaptations.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan

item.title: ‘The Pitt,’ Plus 10 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The series, set in a Pittsburgh emergency room and starring Noah Wyle, returns. And a new group of players enter a castle in Scotland for “The Traitors.”
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: Critics Choice Awards 2026: The Complete Winners List
item.description: “One Battle After Another” won best picture, while the top acting honors went to Timothée Chalamet (“Marty Supreme”) and Jessie Buckley (“Hamnet”).
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:description: From left, Benicio del Toro, Leonardo DiCaprio, the casting director Cassandra Kulukundis, the director Paul Thomas Anderson and Chase Infiniti, accepting best picture for “One Battle After Another.”

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2: Behind the Scenes with Noah Wyle
item.description: Noah Wyle and his castmates turned one harrowing day at an E.R. into an unforgettable season of television. Can they do it again?
item.dc:creator: Sam Anderson
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson/Redux, for The New York Times
item.media:description: The actor Noah Wyle on the set of the HBO Max hospital drama “The Pitt.”

item.title: Kevin O’Leary on ‘Marty Supreme’ and Notes He Gave Josh Safdie
item.description: When it came to his film acting debut, the“Shark Tank” investor had some notes for the director Josh Safdie.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: For the movie, O’Leary wore two watches, one on each wrist: one set to New York time, the other set to Tokyo time.
